#Text=Avoid Traffic Jams
#Text=Nothing ruins an otherwise perfect day like getting stuck in a traffic jam .
#Text=By planning your journey ahead , however , you can avoid most congestion .
#Text=There are also a number of technological tools that can help you skirt traffic issues , even in real time .
#Text=You can also consider changing the times you travel at and transportation methods , especially if you live in an area that is constantly prone to traffic jams .
#Text=With a little planning , you 'll reach your destination without raising your blood pressure .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Planning Alternate Routes
#Text=Listen to traffic reports before you begin your journey .
#Text=Local television news programs often give morning and afternoon traffic reports to help commuters .
#Text=Some locations also have dedicated traffic radio .
#Text=Tune into these before you get in the car .
#Text=If it sounds like traffic is backed up on your normal route , take one of your alternatives .
#Text=Put your GPS to work .
#Text=Many GPS systems have built-in traffic flow monitoring .
#Text=These can alert you when a route is affected by a traffic jam .
#Text=Some can even automatically change your route to a clearer one .
#Text=Check the instructions for your model to see what capabilities it has , and how to set up the traffic monitoring features .
#Text=Use traffic apps .
#Text=The navigation tools built into most smartphones have the ability to detect traffic problems , much like dedicated GPS devices .
#Text=There are also apps like Waze that you can install and use to help avoid traffic jams .
#Text=Traffic apps may have special features like real time camera feeds to view traffic conditions , or social features to help you connect with other drivers and learn about various routes .
#Text=If you just your phone to help avoid traffic jams , be sure not to check it while you are actually driving .
#Text=Do n’t fear the HOV lane .
#Text=Cities that have freeways often devote one of the lanes to High Occupancy Vehicles ( HOVs ) , or ones that have at least two people riding in them ( including the driver ) .
#Text=These almost always have fewer cars , which means less congestion .
#Text=Give the HOV lane a chance and see if it helps you avoid jams .
#Text=Learn several ways to reach your destination .
#Text=Most destinations in busy locations can be reached by several ways .
#Text=Before you go , look up several routes , including the fastest , the shortest , and alternatives that may take you down side-streets .
#Text=You can take one of the alternatives if you expect a traffic jam , saving you time and stress .
#Text=Use maps or apps to research possible routes .
#Text=You can also ask other people which routes they take to avoid traffic congestion .
#Text=Changing Your Travel Plans
#Text=Avoid rush hour .
#Text=The early morning and late afternoon hours are the worst traffic times in most locations , because that is when most people are on the road commuting to and from work/school .
#Text=If at all possible , avoid driving during these times .
#Text=Leaving just a little bit earlier or later can help you steer clear of tailgating traffic. .
#Text=Ask to change shifts at work if possible .
#Text=If you work during the day and have to drive , you still might be able to avoid rush hour .
#Text=Ask your supervisor if you can change shifts so that you come in and leave earlier and later to beat the rush-hour traffic .
#Text=A more involved change is to work from home , but some employers are open to this idea .
#Text=Even if you can work from home only one day a week , that means a little less time spent waiting in traffic jams .
#Text=Make the most of public transportation .
#Text=There are real benefits to public transportation , including decreased traffic overall .
#Text=For you as an individual , it can be a solution for avoiding traffic jams .
#Text=Modes like rail and subways bypass roads altogether .
#Text=Even bus routes are usually planned to get people where they need to go efficiently .
#Text=Sit back , relax , and let someone else do the driving !

#Text=You can even have a nap on the journey if you wish , and unlike an ordinary car driver , buses are permitted to use bus lanes which are far less congested than other lanes reserved for other traffic .
#Text=Enjoy the freedom of two feet or wheels .
#Text=If you only have to travel a fairly short distance , try not to drive at all .
#Text=If it ’s a walkable distance , there ’s no need to get stuck behind the wheel .
#Text=You can also try cycling , especially if there are dedicated cycle lanes in your area .
#Text=This can be more direct , enjoyable and is healthier than driving .
#Text=Walking and cycling are great choices for your health : you can lose weight , get exercise , and do your bit to help save the environment .
#Text=In some locations , motorcycles and scooters are allowed to drive between lanes of traffic .
#Text=If this is allowed in your area , this can be another option for escaping a traffic jam .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Most traffic jams are not caused by accidents , but by drivers following too closely behind another car , requiring them to brake .
#Text=This causes a chain reaction so that every car behind them has to brake , too , slowing down the flow of traffic .
#Text=Keep a reasonable distance behind the car in front of you to avoid this problem .
#Text=Also , agricultural workers driving slow-moving farm vehicles can cause major tailbacks and often delay other commuters ' journeys .
#Text=So if you work in the primary sector , avoid driving one of these during peak times .
#Text=Another common cause of traffic jams happens when drivers refuse to let other drivers merge in when lanes reduce in number .
#Text=Follow the “ zipper ” method to prevent this .
#Text=Let one car ahead of you merge in , then move forward .
#Text=Hopefully , other drivers will do the same !
